translation1: The history of civilization shows how man always has to choose between making the right and the wrong use of the discoveries of science. This has never been more true than in our own age.
translation10: It is morally justifiable to make any perfect discoveries an inventions which can be used for purpose of destruction.
translation2: In a brief period amazing discoveries have been made and applied to practical purposes. It has become platitude to say we are living in an age of revolution. it would be ungrateful not to recognize how immense are the boons which science has given to mankind. It has brought within reach of multitudes benefits and advantages which only a short time ago were the privilege of the few.it has shown how malnutrition, hunger and disease can be overcome.
translation3: It has not only lengthened life but it has deepened its quality. Fields of knowledge, experience and recreation often in the past only to a few have been thrown open to millions.
translation4: But the gifts of modern science can be misused.
translation5: Through the work of science ordinary man today has been given the opportunity of a longer and fuller life than was ever possible to his grandparents. Most thankfully we must acknowledge all that science has done and is doing for the welfare of our race. but the gifts of modern science can be misused.
translation6: The motor-driven vehicle facilitates business and gives harmless enjoyment to many; but it can strew the roads with dead and dying-over more causalities in one year in this country alone.
translation7: The cinema is a means of instruction and recreation opening magic casements, but it is often any channel of vulgarity and false values.
translation8: The wireless can link the world together in a moment of time, but it can also be the instrument of lying propaganda. The aeroplane makes travel rapid and easily.
translation9: It can also become a weapon of destruction. It is this two-fold aspect of the use to which science can be put that has raised in an acute form the question.

translation1: Consequences of noises.
translation10: If we live in industrial areas which are growing with every passing year, there is the deafening noise produced by the speakers in house or shops, radio sets in the neighborhood, school children at play or at chorus practice of arithmetical tables, and so on.
translation2: many of us who live in large towns and cities have grown used to working in noise which comes from several different sources. There is the noise of moving trains which is heard at almost all hours of the day.
translation3: The Jet planes that fly over head produce noise of even greater loudness and intensity.
translation4: Most of us have no time to think of noises on one type or another.
translation5: They become part of our daily lives.
translation6: But there is something to be thought of-does noise affect our lives in some harmful ways.
translation7: already there is evidence that it does so in several ways. It has been recognized for a long time.
translation8: Now that exposure to noise high intensity leads to loss of hearing. There have been cases of boiler-makers, for example, whose suffer from occupational deafness.
translation9: More recently it has also been found that people who are continuously exposed to other loud noises require protection of the ear.

translation2: Today, as I was returning to my shop, after Isha prayer, when a man sitting in a car at the circle raised his hand and diverted my attention towards him.
translation3: I thought this man might have lost his way, or he might want to ask something, so I stopped, and his whole family was sitting in the car.
translation4: He asked whether I could understand Arabic well or not. I said no problem, tell me what you want.
translation5: He started to say that I have come from Riyadh, to Madinah, but someone has pick-pocketed me, so please help me out. I asked him to excuse me, as such an incident had taken place with me previously, that I had given the person 20 Riyals to buy petrol to reach Riyadh, but he went a little ahead and started to ask somebody else.
translation6: I got very angry and scolded him and warned him that I would call the soldiers, so he got very frightened.
translation7: Now the situation  has become, that we Muslims come on cars, with our families to beg throughout the day and gain at least two or three thousand illegally.
translation8: Whereas there is a clear Hadith of the Prophet (SAWS) that says that the upper hand is better than the lower hand; the lower hand being the begging hand and the upper hand being the giving one.
translation9: May Allah have mercy on us and make us true Muslims (Amen, Amen)
